grammar_tips.title: De vs Het - Basic Rules
grammar_tips.explanation: Most Dutch nouns use 'de' (75%), but some use 'het'. Common 'het' words include diminutives (-je, -tje), infinitives used as nouns, and metals/languages.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de man, het huis, het meisje
grammar_tips.english_example: the man, the house, the girl

grammar_tips.title: Verb Past Tense Formation
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch past tense is formed by adding -de/-te to the verb stem. Use -te after unvoiced consonants (t, k, f, s, ch, p), otherwise use -de.
grammar_tips.english_example: to work → worked, to make → made

grammar_tips.title: Plural Formation with -en
grammar_tips.explanation: Most Dutch nouns form their plural by adding -en. This is the most common plural form in Dutch.

grammar_tips.title: Adjective Endings with -e
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch adjectives get an -e ending when used before the noun with 'de' or 'het' (definite), or before plural nouns.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de grote hond, een groot huis
grammar_tips.english_example: the big dog, a big house

grammar_tips.title: Modal Verbs Usage
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch modal verbs (kunnen, willen, moeten, mogen) are followed by an infinitive that goes to the end of the sentence.

grammar_tips.title: Separable Verbs
grammar_tips.explanation: Many Dutch verbs have separable prefixes. In present tense, the prefix goes to the end of the sentence.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: opstaan → Ik sta om 7 uur op
grammar_tips.english_example: to get up → I get up at 7 o'clock

grammar_tips.title: Diminutives Always Use 'Het'
grammar_tips.explanation: All diminutives (words ending in -je, -tje, -etje, -pje) always use 'het', regardless of the gender of the original word.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de kat → het katje, de boom → het boompje
grammar_tips.english_example: the cat → the little cat, the tree → the little tree

grammar_tips.title: Past Participle Formation
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch past participles usually start with 'ge-' and end with -d or -t. Use -t after unvoiced consonants, -d otherwise.
grammar_tips.english_example: to work → worked, to make → made

grammar_tips.title: Dutch Word Order (V2 Rule)
grammar_tips.explanation: In Dutch main clauses, the finite verb always comes second. This is called the V2 rule.

grammar_tips.title: Body Parts with Articles
grammar_tips.explanation: Most body parts use 'de' article in Dutch. Some exceptions use 'het': het hoofd (head), het lichaam (body), het hart (heart).
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de hand, het hoofd, de voet
grammar_tips.english_example: the hand, the head, the foot

grammar_tips.title: Compound Words with -kamer
grammar_tips.explanation: Many rooms in Dutch are formed by adding '-kamer' (room) to a function word: slaap+kamer, bad+kamer, woon+kamer, eet+kamer.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de slaapkamer, de badkamer, de woonkamer
grammar_tips.english_example: the bedroom, the bathroom, the living room

grammar_tips.title: Home Appliances with 'Het'
grammar_tips.explanation: Most household appliances and technical devices use 'het': het fornuis, het bed, het raam. But 'de' is used for: de keuken, de tuin, de garage.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: het fornuis, de keuken, het raam
grammar_tips.english_example: the stove, the kitchen, the window

grammar_tips.title: Compound Appliances
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch combines words to name appliances: koel+kast (refrigerator), was+machine (washing machine), stofzuiger (vacuum = dust sucker).
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de koelkast, de wasmachine, de stofzuiger
grammar_tips.english_example: the refrigerator, the washing machine, the vacuum cleaner

grammar_tips.title: Location in the House
grammar_tips.explanation: Use 'in de/het' for inside rooms: 'in de keuken', 'in het huis'. Use 'op' for surfaces: 'op de tafel', 'op de vloer'.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: in de keuken, op de tafel, in het huis
grammar_tips.english_example: in the kitchen, on the table, in the house

grammar_tips.title: Rooms and Spaces Articles
grammar_tips.explanation: Most rooms use 'de': de keuken, de kamer, de tuin, de garage. But 'het huis' (the house) uses 'het'.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: de keuken, de kamer, het huis
grammar_tips.english_example: the kitchen, the room, the house

grammar_tips.title: Prepositions with Location
grammar_tips.explanation: Dutch uses different prepositions for location vs. direction. 'in/op/aan' for location, 'naar/in' for direction.
grammar_tips.dutch_example: in het huis (location), naar het huis (direction)
grammar_tips.english_example: in the house (location), to the house (direction)
